content: The term "conspiracy theory" was first introduced into the lexicon in the late 1960s, specifically in the year 1967. The phrase was used in a 1967 article by American political scientist, Richard Hofstadter, titled "The Paranoid Style in American Politics," which was published in Harper's Magazine. Hofstadter used the term to describe a certain type of political attitude, which he described as "the sense of heated exaggeration, suspiciousness, and conspiratorial fantasy" that he saw in some political movements of the time. He wrote that "American politics has often been an arena for angry minds" and that "in recent years we have seen angry minds at work mainly among extreme right-wingers."
